data.title: Scrolling is not as smooth as it used to be
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|0.7.2|

---

When working with a "high precision" touch pad and using the two finger scroll it doesn't seem as "smooth" in the code editor as it did in previous versions of VS Code. When you first starting moving the fingers it takes a bit of time before it starts moving and then it "jumps". Once the scrolling is activated it is smooth, but once you let go of the fingers on the touch pad and then start again, it again has a delay before the scroll starts.

It should work just as smooth as it does in e.g. Chrome or Edge. This to me was one of the great advantages with VS Code over the full VS, so I am sad that we've lost the smooth scrolling again.

I'm on a Dell XPS15 and the touch pad should be a top-of-the-line touchpad (high precision).

data.title: Unable to open folder from task list that contains spaces
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a folder that contains whitespaces on windows 
2. stop VS Code
3. start VS Code
4. stop VS Code (workaround needed to make the folder show up in task list)
5. right click on task list and pick the folder with spaces

=> it does not open, instead it opens with 2 dirty files

data.title: updatable git menu (feature request)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open Git tab
2. wait while git start refreshing
3. open "More" menu to make pull

Expected: "More" menu with mass of disabled items while git refreshing is active. But when it finished, disabled items start to be active. Or all items is active always, but if git refreshing is active all actions write in the queue.

Actual: "More" menu with mass of disabled items. User have to reopen it to catch moment when refreshing is done, when all required items will be active.

data.title: Node debugger does not stop at breakpoints in CoffeeScript source file of Meteor app
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 7
- Meteor Version:  1.4.1.3

Steps to Reproduce:

I am trying to use sequentially the node debugger and the chrome debugger extension to debug a CoffeeScript leaderboard toy app using the dual, client and server sides, full-stack framework Meteor.
I put breakpoints in the server-side only code and in the client-side only code.

 I use the following VSCode Extensions:
- Meteor-Helper 0.1.1
- Debugger for Chrome 2.2.0

Since
1) Meteor is a dual side framework with
- client-side only code
- server-side only code
- isomorphic code running on both sides

and
2) According to Rob Lourens who is helping me with the chrome debugger extension issues, VSCode currently does **_not_** support **_launching simultaneously

_** both the server-side code built-in node debugger and the client-side code chrome debugger extension

I thus proceed as follow:
- I have an **Attach Server configuration in my launch.json file**
{
            "name": "Attach Server",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 5858,
            "address": "localhost",
            "restart": false,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outFiles": ["${workspaceRoot}/.meteor/local/build/programs/server/app/app.js"],
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": null
        },
- I have an **Attach Client configuration in my launch.json file**
{
            "name": "Attach Client",
            "type": "chrome",
            "request": "attach",
            "port": 9222,
            "address": "localhost",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "outFiles": ["${workspaceRoot}/.meteor/local/build/programs/web.browser/app/app.js"],
            "diagnosticLogging": true,
            "webRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "url": "http://localhost:3000/"
        }

I put breakpoints in the server-side only app startup function.

1. Using Meteor-Helper, I execute the meteor debug command

2. I  then attach the node debugger.
VSCode ignores the breakpoints and goes on to execute the entire app until the point when the app is waiting for a user action.

3. At that point the breakpoints have turned hollow and grey and a hovering message says:

> breakpoints ignored because generated code not found (soure map problem?)

4. The output window tells me that the app is running at: http://localhost:3000/

5. When I click on this url, VSCode opens the fs.js file (node file system) and stops before the return statement of the fs.statSync function defintion with the call stack saying "paused on exception and a blank page opens in my chrome browser saying "waiting for localhost"

![vscodenodedebuggernotstoppingatbreakpoints future js exception](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8970048/20043529/262395aa-a48f-11e6-83bf-a20cddad83aa.jpeg)

6. Then when I click on the play icon of the node debugger, VSCode opens the future.js file, stopped at the  throw error line of the Future.prototype assignement statement and generating a Mongo Error connection time out

7. It is only when I pause the node debugger that the first page of my app finally appears in the browser
![vscodenodedebuggerissueafterpause](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8970048/20043530/289a0a58-a48f-11e6-8dca-d0f37269b417.jpeg)

**The Meteor packages I used are:**
meteor-base@1.0.4             # Packages every Meteor app needs to have
mobile-experience@1.0.4       # Packages for a great mobile UX
mongo@1.1.12                   # The database Meteor supports right now
blaze-html-templates@1.0.4    # Compile .html files into Meteor Blaze views
reactive-var@1.0.10            # Reactive variable for tracker
jquery@1.11.9                  # Helpful client-side library
tracker@1.1.0                 # Meteor's client-side reactive programming library

standard-minifier-css@1.2.0   # CSS minifier run for production mode
standard-minifier-js@1.2.0    # JS minifier run for production mode
es5-shim@4.6.14                # ECMAScript 5 compatibility for older browsers.
ecmascript@0.5.8              # Enable ECMAScript2015+ syntax in app code
shell-server@0.2.1            # Server-side component of the `meteor shell` command

autopublish@1.0.7             # Publish all data to the clients (for prototyping)
insecure@1.0.7                # Allow all DB writes from clients (for prototyping)

coffeescript@1.11.1_1
mquandalle:jade@0.4.9
stylus@2.513.5

**The CoffeeScript source code is:**
(I chose Insert code, but it did not preserve the white spaces :( )
`class Player
  constructor: (@name, @score = Math.floor(Math.random() * 10)) ->

class Leaderboard extends Mongo.Collection
  insertNewPlayer: (playerName, score) ->
    player = new Player(playerName, score)
    @insert player

  insertPlayers: (nameList, scoreList) ->
    @insertNewPlayer(playerName) for playerName in nameList
    @insert(_id:player._id, score) for score in scoreList
    # self = @

  rank: =>
    [lead, followers...] = @find({}, {sort: {score: -1, name: 1}}).fetch()
    rank = 1
    @update {_id: lead._id}, {$set: {rank: rank}}
    previousScore = lead.score
    tiedCounter = 1
    for player in followers
      do (player) =>
        if player.score is previousScore
          tiedCounter = tiedCounter + 1
        else
          rank = rank + tiedCounter
          tiedCounter = 1
        @update _id: player._id, {$set: rank: rank}
        previousScore = player.score
    # self = @

aflLeaders = new Leaderboard("aflLeaders") unless aflLeaders?

if Meteor.isClient
  Template.leaderboard.helpers
    players: -> aflLeaders.find {}, {sort: {score: -1, name: 1}}

  Template.player.events
    'click tr>td>button': ->
      @score = @score + 1
      aflLeaders.update {_id: @_id}, @
      aflLeaders.rank()
      self = aflLeaders
     
if Meteor.isServer
  Meteor.startup ->
    if not (aflLeaders? and aflLeaders.findOne({})?)
      aflLeaders.insertPlayers([
        "Heath Shaw"
        "Alex Rance"
        "Easton Wood"
        "Shaun Burgoyne"
        "Jeremy McGovern"
        "Matthew Boyd"
        "Robbie Gray"
        "Josh P. Kennedy"
        "Patrick Dangerfield"
        "Callan Ward"
        "Max Gawn"
        "Rory Sloane"
        "Toby Greene"
        "Lance Franklin"
        "Cyril Rioli"
        "Eddie Betts"
        "Josh J. Kennedy"
        "Jack Gunston"
        "Josh Gibson"
        "Liam Picken"
        "Marcus Bontempelli"
        "Rory Lobb"
        ],
        []
      )
      aflLeaders.rank()
    self = aflLeaders`

**The jade template file I used is**:
` head
  title Leaderboard

body
  +leaderboard

template(name="leaderboard")
  tr
    th(colspan="4")
      h4 Leaderboard
  tr#sortButtonRaw
    th#sortButtonCell
      p rank
    th
      p player
    th
      p score
    th
  +each players
    +player

template(name="player")
  tr
    td
      p= rank
    td
      p= name
    td
      p= score
    td
      button vote` 

I don't know if this is:
- a node debugger bug, or
- a bug in the Attach Server configuration of my launch.json file.

But with the very limited documentation currently available concerning what attributes to use and with what values to obtain what debugging behavior in such file, I can't figure out how to set it up correctly for a Meteor app programmed in CoffeeScript with the many sources maps that the build process of such app generates.

Thanks in advance for helping out of this quicksand.

data.title: Performance drop on fullscreen with hardware acceleration enabled
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
Go fullscreen, as far as I can tell. Specs: gsync, 1070, 6700K.

When I go fullscreen, my framerate drops by a lot, to about 3-30 on the low side. This is fine when it's not drawing, but when I pick up my cursor to move, edit, etc., it's slow to kick into gear and feels laggy.

data.title: ctrl+1 and ctrl+2 do not change focus.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
On my computer they just don't work. Even with the following key config, ctrl+k j and ctrl+k l do what they're supposed to, but ctrl+1 and ctrl+2 do not.
[
{ "key": "ctrl+k ctrl+j",           "command": "workbench.action.moveActiveEditorGroupLeft" },
{ "key": "ctrl+k ctrl+l",          "command": "workbench.action.moveActiveEditorGroupRight" },
{ "key": "ctrl+1",     "command": "workbench.action.focusPreviousGroup" },
{ "key": "ctrl+2",      "command": "workbench.action.focusNextGroup" },
{ "key": "ctrl+k j",     "command": "workbench.action.focusPreviousGroup" },
{ "key": "ctrl+k l",      "command": "workbench.action.focusNextGroup" }
]

data.title: JavaScript syntax highlighting for new expressions w/ white spaces
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

var foo = new  Foo(whatever)  whatever is highlighted the standard way
var foo = new  Foo (whatever)  whatever is not highlighted (e.g. all teal in default light)

It's a minor thing but it'll be great if the white space before the opening parenthesis would be tolerated (some people format that way).

data.title: Support piping text into the editor from the command line

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.1

With the `code` command installed in your PATH it should be possible to pipe text into the editor from the command line:

```
$ curl -L bing.com | code
```

In this example, Id expect Code to open and show me the output of the `curl` command (which would be the HTML of the Bing home page).

This works with Sublime Text (`subl` command) and TextMate (`mate` command). It would be great if `code` did this too.

data.title: Incremental Replacement should not depend on focus. (No keybinding to replace current match.)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In any file, highlight the text to find.
2. Trigger the `actions.find` command (`Ctrl+F`).
3. To replace the current match, move cursor focus to the "Replace" box of the Find+Replace dialog and press `ENTER`.

This is a problem because it is tedious to change focus (as compared to having a dedicated keybinding to replace the currently active target).

In the full Visual Studio this is done by hitting `Alt+R`, which works no matter where the focus is within the Find+Replace dialog.

data.title: Triggering actions.find causes active match to lose its highlight.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In any file, highlight the text to find.
2. Trigger the `actions.find` command with the keyboard (`Ctrl+F`).
3. Observe that the originally highlighted text is not highlighted in any way that distinguishes it as the active match or target for replacement.

Alternate Steps to Reproduce:

1. In any file, highlight the text to find.
2. Trigger the `editor.action.startFindReplaceAction` command with the keyboard (`Ctrl+H`).
3. Observe that the originally highlighted text is not highlighted in any way that distinguishes it as the active match or target for replacement.

Example of both Steps and Alternate Steps shown in the following gif. In the gif, you can see that whenever the Find/Find+Replace box is shown, the originally highlighted text is no longer marked as the active match, even though it is the active match.

This is a major problem because there is no way to confirm what the very first replacement will be.

![vscode-find-replace](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/623736/20039981/9d36c112-a41c-11e6-9b6c-7c8151d255c0.gif)

data.title: Plugin feature request: new default setting value
data.body:
A plugin author may have knowledge about their users' development environments that could be productively expressed as new default values for some builtin vscode settings.

As one real world example, Polymer code makes use of a mix of CSS features which don't currently validate with the built in css language server. It would be useful if installing the polymer vscode plugin set the default value of `css.validate` to false, in a way that was still overridable by user or workspace settings.

data.title: Escape special characters like !,?,' ' in Terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.1 (1.7.1) 02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44
- OS Version: 10.12.1 (16B2555)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Terminal in VSCode
2. Execute a gulp task with a **child_process.exec** command with a string like that:
`mkdir -p ../!deploy`
or
`mkdir -p ../\!deploy`

Neither of the two command/tasks above work as expected in the internal Terminal. In iTerm.app both examples are working as expected.

How do I have to escape special characters like **?**, **!** or **whitespace** in paths to be able to execute a gulp task with **child_process.exec**?

data.title: How do I support new features added in Code 1.7 in my extension while still supporting users on Code 1.6?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: Windows 10

I can't find any good information on the relationship between the Code `engine` version in `package.json` and versions of other parts (like the `vscode` `devDependency`).

It seems that updating the `engine` number causes a new `vscode.d.ts` to be downloaded when I run `npm install`, however I believe that also sets the minimum required Code version to install the extension.

If that's correct, I'm not sure how I can get the latest `vscode.d.ts` so that I can (for example) add [`evaluateName`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10210) support but still allow the extension to be installed by Code 1.6 users?

It's also not clear how the other versions relate - do I need to move the `vscode` `devDependency` version forwards whenever I update the `engine` version? If so, is there a table of the min versions that work together?

Apologies if this is covered somewhere - I can't find it. Maybe if it doesn't exist, it's worth a small page in the extension docs explaining the relationship between these versions and the process/implications of updating each one.
